Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Patient-Specific and Conventional Instrumentation in Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, 100 patients scheduled for TKA were randomised

Participants.evidence: The trial was conducted at a single orthopedic center, with recruitment from January 2020 to June 2021.

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either patient-specific instruments (n=50) or conventional instruments (n=50)

Objective.evidence: This study investigates whether patient-specific CT-based instrumentation offers improved precision and reliability over conventional instrumentation in total knee arthroplasty (TKA).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of outliers in postoperative hip-knee-ankle angles, assessed within 6 weeks post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group allocation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 100 patients scheduled for TKA were randomised to receive either patient-specific instruments (n=50) or conventional instruments (n=50)

Result_Outcome.evidence: The incidence of outliers in hip-knee-ankle angles was similar between groups, with 12% in the patient-specific group and 10% in the conventional group (p=0.75).

Harms.evidence: No severe adverse events were reported in either group.
